case_data.name: Parenti v. County of Monterey
case_data.plaintiff_description: The estate of an inmate who died in jail.
case_data.summary:
On December 16, 2014, the estate of an inmate who died in jail filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs sued Monterey County, the Monterey County Sheriff, the Monterey County Jail, and the California Forensic Medical Group under 42 U.S.C. ยง1983. Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought monetary and injunctive relief, claiming a failure to provide medical care in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and a deprivation of substantive due process in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs also claimed negligence and wrongful death under California state law. Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants left the inmate lying unconscious, helpless, and untreated in his bed to die from viral influenza syndrome complicated by pneumoniaโa treatable condition. At the time of the inmate's death, the jail was already the subject of a class action lawsuit regarding systemic failures to provide adequate medical care. Hernandez v. County of Monterey. On June 6, 2016, the case was reassigned to Judge Beth Labson Freeman.

On April 21, 2015, the parties agreed to enter into settlement negotiations; a settlement conference was scheduled for October 30, 2015. The parties could not come to a settlement agreement at that conference. Further settlement discussions continued through April and June 2017, but the parties did not settle.

In October 2017, the plaintiff filed a stipulation and proposed order with the court for the dismissal of defendant California Forensic Medical Group. The court approved it.

That same day, the defendant Sheriff filed a motion for partial summary judgment as to the claims against him. He claimed that he could not be liable because the plaintiffs could not show that on January 15, 2014, the defendant Sheriff knew the plaintiff had faced a substantial risk of serious harm and disregarded that risk by failing to take reasonable steps to abate it. Moreover, the defendant Sheriff argued that the doctrine of qualified immunity shielded him from liability for civil damages because his conduct did not violate clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person would have known.

On April 6, 2018, the court granted in part and denied in part this defendant Sheriffโs motion. Judge Freeman granted the motion as to the plaintiff's first cause of action pursuant to ยง 1983 for deliberate indifference to the plaintiff's serious medical needs in violation of the Eighth Amendment and granted the motion as to Plaintiffsโ second cause of action pursuant to ยง 1983 for loss of the parent/child relationship in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment. These claims were dismissed. The court denied the motion, however, as to the plaintiffsโ alleged violations of California state tort law.

The parties continued to engage in discovery and motion in limine briefing through the rest of 2018. At the same time, they continued to engage in settlement conferences and reached a settlement for monetary damages in early 2019. On January 23, 2019, the plaintiff filed a motion for settlement approval. The court approved the settlement agreement on March 18, 2019. The plaintiff then voluntarily dismissed the case on April 29, 2019. This case is closed.
case_data.summary_short: In 2014, the estate of an inmate who died in jail filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs sued Monterey County and other defendants under 42 U.S.C. ยง1983. The plaintiffs claimed a failure to provide medical care in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and a deprivation of substantive due process in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The parties settled on March 18, 2019 and case was dismissed on April 29, 2019.

3  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
4  A.  Summary Judgment 
5  โA party is entitled to summary judgment if the โmovant shows that there is no genuine 
6  dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โโ  City of 
7  Pomona v. SQM N. Am. Corp., 750 F.3d 1036, 1049 (9th Cir. 2014) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 
8  56(a)).  Material facts are those that may affect the outcome of the case.  Anderson v. Liberty 
9  Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A genuine dispute of material fact exists if there is sufficient 
10  evidence for a reasonable jury to return a verdict for the nonmoving party.  Id. at 248โ49. 
11  The party moving for summary judgment bears the initial burden of informing the court of 
12  the basis for the motion, and identifying portions of the pleadings, depositions, answers to 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  interrogatories, admissions, or affidavits that demonstrate the absence of a triable issue of material 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  fact.  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986).  To meet its burden, โthe moving party 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  must either produce evidence negating an essential element of the nonmoving partyโs claim or 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  defense or show that the nonmoving party does not have enough evidence of an essential element 
S d nr
ee 17  to carry its ultimate burden of persuasion at trial.โ  Nissan Fire & Marine Ins. Co., Ltd. v. Fritz 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Cos., Inc., 210 F.3d 1099, 1102 (9th Cir. 2000). 
19  If the moving party meets its initial burden, the burden shifts to the nonmoving party to 
20  produce evidence supporting its claims or defenses.  Id. at 1103.  If the nonmoving party does not 
21  produce evidence to show a genuine issue of material fact, the moving party is entitled to 
22  summary judgment.  Celotex, 477 U.S. at 323.  It is not the task of the Court to scour the record in 
23  search of a genuine issue of triable fact. Keenan v. Allan, 91 F.3d 1275, 1279 (9th Cir. 1996).  The 
24

2  precludes summary judgment.โ Id.; see also Simmons v. Navajo Cnty., Ariz., 609 F.3d 1011, 1017 
3  (9th Cir. 2010).  Thus, โ[t]he district court need not examine the entire file for evidence 
4  establishing a genuine issue of fact, where the evidence is not set forth in the opposing papers with

6  Sch. Dist., 237 F.3d 1026, 1031 (9th Cir. 2001).   
7  โThe court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmovant and draw 
8  all reasonable inferences in the nonmovantโs favor.โ  City of Pomona, 750 F.3d at 1049.  
9  However, โthe โmere existence of a scintilla of evidence in support of the plaintiffโs positionโโ is 
10  insufficient to defeat a motion for summary judgment.  Id. (quoting Anderson, 477 U.S. 242, 252 
11  (1986)).  โโWhere the record taken as a whole could not lead a rational trier of fact to find for the

8  second step is to determine whether the right was clearly established. Id.  โThe relevant, 
9  dispositive inquiry in determining whether a right is clearly established is whether it would be 
10  clear to a reasonable officer that his conduct was unlawful in the situation he confronted.โ Id. at

26  with deliberate indifference to the inmateโs health or safety.โ Lemire, 726 F.3d at 1074.  To satisfy 
27  the subjective component of deliberate indifference, Plaintiffs must show that Deputy Collins 
28  โknew of and disregardedโ the substantial risk of harm.  Id.  The prison official need not have

3  โDeliberate indifference is a high legal standard.โ  Toguchi v. Chung, 391 F.3d 1051, 1060 
4  (9th Cir. 2004).  A showing of medical malpractice or mere negligence is insufficient to establish a 
5  constitutional deprivation under the Eighth Amendment.  Id.  Rather, deliberate indifference lies 
6  โsomewhere between the poles of negligence at one end and purpose or knowledge at the other.โ 
7  Farmer v. Brennan, 511 U.S. 825, 836 (1994).  Under the deliberate indifference standard, the 
8  prison official must not only โbe aware of facts from which the inference could be drawn that a 
9  substantial risk of serious harm exists,โ but that person โmust also draw the inference.โ Id. 
10  (quoting Farmer, 511 U.S. at 837).  Liability may follow only if a prison official โknows that 
11  inmates face a substantial risk of serious harm and disregards that risk by failing to take reasonable 
12  measures to abate it.โ Labatad, 714 F.3d at 1160 (quoting Farmer, 511 U.S. at 847); see

4  Code ยง 377.60).  โA wrongful death claim may be predicated on negligence or other tortious 
5  conduct.โ Prasad, 958 F. Supp. 2d 1101, 1118 (E.D. Cal. 2013). 
6  Deputy Collins argues that he is entitled to statutory immunity on the negligence and 
7  wrongful death claims under the immunity provided by California Government Code section 
8  845.6.  Mot. at 15; Reply at 8.  That section provides in part that โ[n]either a public entity nor a 
9  public employee is liable for injury proximately caused by the failure of the employee to furnish or 
10  obtain medical care for a prisoner in his custody.โ Cal. Govโt Code ยง 845.6 (West).  An exception 
11  exists โif the employee knows or has reason to know that the prisoner is in need of immediate 
12  medical care and he fails to take reasonable action to summon such medical care.โ Id.   
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  โLiability of public entities and public employees under Government Code section 845.6 is 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  limited to serious and obvious medical conditions requiring immediate care.โ  Lucas v. Cty. of Los 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Angeles, 47 Cal. App. 4th 277, 288 (1996) (citing Watson v. State of California, 21 Cal.App.4th 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  836, 841 (1993)).  Under California law, the duty of such public entities and officials to provide 
S d nr
ee 17  medical care to prisoners is limited to โcases where there is actual or constructive knowledge that 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the prisoner is in need of immediate medical care.โ Id.  This is an objective standard.  Id.  
19  โ[S]ection 845.6 creates out of the general immunity a limited cause of action against a public 
20  entity for its employeesโ failure to summon immediate medical care onlyโฆThe statute does not 
21  create liability of the public entity for malpractice in furnishing or obtaining that medical 
22  care.โ  Frary v. Cty. of Marin, 81 F. Supp. 3d 811, 842 (N.D. Cal. 2015) (quoting Castaneda v. 
23  Depโt of Corrs. & Rehab., 212 Cal.App.4th 1051, 1070 (2013), review denied (May 1, 2013)).  
24  Deputy Collins essentially argues that the state law claims must fail for the same reasons 
25  that the section 1983 claims fail: because โ[t]here is simply no evidence to establish that Deputy 
26  Collins denied, delayed or interfered with Parentiโs medical treatment.โ Reply at 11.  On this 
27  point, the Court agrees with Plaintiffs that Frary is instructive.  See Oppโn at 24.  In Frary, 
28  although the court found that summary judgment was appropriate against certain deputies because 
29 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 109   Filed 04/06/18   Page 30 of 31
 
1  section 845.6 does not impose a duty to monitor the quality of care provided, summary judgment 
2  was denied as to Deputy Hammer based on evidence similar to the record in this case. 81 F. Supp. 
3  3d at 842-43.  Like Deputy Collins in this case, Deputy Hammer in Frary was not able to rouse an 
4  inmate who had medical issues after repeatedly yelling and knocking loudly at his door.  Deputy 
5  Hammer took no action to summon medical assistance or to inform other deputies that the inmate 
6  was unresponsive despite repeated knocking and yelling.  With respect to section 845.6, the Frary 
7  court held that โthere is at least a triable issue of fact as to whether [Deputy Hammer] knew or had 
8  reason to know that [the inmate] had an immediate medical need.โ Id.   
9  Here, it is the โreason to knowโ language that differentiates Plaintiffsโ state law causes of 
10  action from the deliberate indifference standard analyzed above.  Courts have construed the 
11  โknows or has reason to knowโ element in 845.6 to include constructive notice.  See e.g. Lucas v. 
12  Cnty. of L.A., 47 Cal. App. 4th 277, 288 (1996) (holding that the โreason to knowโ in ยง 845.6 is an 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  โobjective standardโ and finding that the duty to provide medical care under ยง 845.6 includes 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  โcases where there is actual or constructive knowledge that the prisoner is in need of immediate 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  medical care.โ) Although Plaintiffs have failed to demonstrate a triable issue of material fact with 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  respect to whether Deputy Collins was deliberately indifferent to Mr. Parentiโs serious medical 
S d nr
ee 17  needs, there is a triable issue with respect to whether Deputy Collins had โreason to knowโ of such 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  needs and could therefore be liable under state law.  Summary judgment on the negligence and 
19  wrongful death claims would therefore be inappropriate. 16   
20  A reasonable jury could conclude from Plaintiffsโ evidence that Mr. Parentiโs failure to 
21  respond to being called and shaken was an indication of an immediate medical need, and that 
22  Deputy Collins had reason to know of that need, but failed to take reasonable actions to summon 
23  medical care.  For these reasons, summary judgment on Plaintiffsโ state law causes of action 
24  against Deputy Collins is DENIED.  
25 
26                                                   
16 This analysis also serves as an independent basis for the denial of Deputy Collinsโ motion for 
27 
summary judgment on the third cause of action for failure to furnish/summon medical care 
pursuant to Government Code sections 844.6 and 845.6.   
28 
 
30 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 109   Filed 04/06/18   Page 31 of 31
 
1    IV.  ORDER 
2    For the foregoing reasons, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that Deputy Collinsโ motion for 
3  partial summary judgment is: 
4  (1)  GRANTED as to Plaintiffsโ first cause of action pursuant to ยง 1983 for 
5  deliberate indifference to Mr. Parentiโs serious medical needs and failure to 
6  protect from harm in violation of the Eighth Amendment; 
7  (2)  GRANTED as to Plaintiffsโ second cause of action pursuant to ยง 1983 for loss 
8  of the parent/child relationship in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment; 
9  (3)  DENIED as to Plaintiffsโ third, fifth, and sixth causes of action for violations of 
10  California state law.

documents.text:
Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 88   Filed 05/10/17   Page 1 of 5
 
1   
2   
3   
4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
JACOB PARENTI, et al.,  Case No.14-cv-05481-BLF   (SVK) 
7 
 
Plaintiffs, 
8   
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION 
v. 
TO GRANT IN PART AND DENY IN 
9 
  PART PLAINTIFFSโ MOTION TO 
COUNTY OF MONTEREY, et al.,  EXCLUDE NON-RETAINED EXPERTS  
10 
Defendants.  Re: Dkt. No. 76 
11 
   
  12  Plaintiffs, the Estate of Jacob Parenti, Mr. Parentiโs minor son, and Mr. Parentiโs mother 
a
rt ni
ur
oo 13  (โPlaintiffsโ) assert violations of federal and state law by Monterey County, Sheriff Scott Miller, 
Cif
t al
icC 14  and Deputy Collins (โCounty Defendantsโ), as well as California Forensic Medical Group and Dr. 
strof 
Dict  15  Taylor Fithian (โCFMG Defendantsโ).  On March 30, 2017, Plaintiffs filed a motion to exclude 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  expert testimony of County Defendants and CFMG Defendants in which Plaintiffs asked the Court 
d Srn 
ee 17  to (1) limit the CFMG Defendants to one retained expert on the topics of cause of death and 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  adequacy of medical care, (2) exclude inadmissible opinions of experts retained by the CFMG 
19  Defendants and the County Defendants, and (3) prohibit testimony by CFMG Defendantsโ non-
20  retained experts who were not adequately disclosed as required by Rule 26.  ECF 76.   
21  On May 3, 2017, the District Court granted in part and denied in part Plaintiffsโ motion as 
22  it related to retained experts of both County and CFMG Defendants.  The Court referred the issue 
23  of whether two of CFMG Defendantsโ non-retained experts, Julie Kelly, PA-C and Delmar 
24  Greenleaf, M.D., should be excluded because of CFMG Defendantsโ failure to comply with  
25  Rule 261 disclosure requirements for non-retained experts.  ECF 87.  Having reviewed the motion 
26  and for the reasons discussed below, the undersigned recommends that the District Court grant 
27 
                                                 
28 
1 All references to Rules are to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure unless noted otherwise. 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 88   Filed 05/10/17   Page 2 of 5
 
1  Plaintiffsโ motion in part and limit the testimony of Kelly and Greenleaf as set forth below.  
2  I.  RELEVANT FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
3  On September 2, 2016, the District Court entered a Case Scheduling Order setting an 
4  expert disclosure deadline of October 22, 2016, a rebuttal expert disclosure deadline of November 
5  22, 2016, and an expert discovery cutoff of January 17, 2017.  ECF 61.  On October 21, 2016, 
6  CFMG Defendants served their expert witness disclosures pursuant to Rule 26.   
7  CFMG Defendants disclosed five retained experts and twelve non-retained experts.  Their 
8  listing of non-retained experts identified only each expertโs name, degree, and address.  ECF 76-1 
9  at 90-94.   
10  On November 17, 2016, the Court continued the expert disclosure deadline from 
11  November 22, 2016 to January 18, 2017 and continued the last day for expert depositions from 
  12  January 17, 2017 to August 17, 2017.  ECF 64.    
a
rt ni
ur
oo 13  Plaintiffs and CFMG Defendants met and conferred regarding CFMG Defendantsโ expert 
Cif
t al
icC 14  disclosure.  Plaintiffs identified, among other objections, that CFMG Defendantsโ list of non-
strof 
Dict  15  retained experts failed to provide the information required under Rule 26(a)(2)(C), including a 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  summary of facts and opinions.  On January 11, 2017, CFMG Defendants served an amended 
d Srn 
ee 17  disclosure providing additional, albeit limited, information regarding the expected testimony of the 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  twelve non-retained witnesses, including Kelly and Greenleaf.  ECF 76-2 at 37-40.  CFMG 
19  Defendants disclosed Kelly and Greenleaf as follows: 
 
20  Julie Kelly, PA-C, c/o CDCR Avenal State Prison, P.S. Box 
39, Avenal,  CA 93204;  (559) 386-0587.  Ms.  Kelly will testify 
21  regarding authentication, interpretation and other issues pertaining 
to  her treatment records and treatment  related to  Mr. Parenti in 
22  connection with his health care at Avenal State Prison.  
 
23  Delmar Greenleaf, M.D., c/o CDCR Avenal State Prison, 
P.O. Box 39, Avenal, CA 93204; (559) 386-0587.  Dr. Greenleaf 
24  will testify regarding authentication, interpretation and other issues 
pertaining  to  his  treatment  records  and  treatment  related  to  Mr. 
25  Parenti in connection with his health care at Avenal State Prison. 
26   
27  Plaintiffs, in their motion to exclude filed March 30, 2017, argue that Kelly and Greenleaf 
28  should be stricken because the CFMG Defendantsโ disclosures do not satisfy Rule 26.  ECF 76 at 
2 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 88   Filed 05/10/17   Page 3 of 5
 
1  23-25.  In opposition to Plaintiffโs motion, CFMG Defendants defend only their retained experts 
2  and do not offer a response to Plaintiffsโ arguments regarding the insufficient Rule 26 disclosures 
3  of Kelly and Greenleaf.  See generally ECF 80.2   
4  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
5  A party must disclose to other parties the identity of any witness it may use at trial to 
6  present expert testimony.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(a)(2)(A). โUnless otherwise stipulated or ordered by 
7  the court, this disclosure must be accompanied by a written report . . . if the witness is one retained 
8  or specially employed to provide expert testimony . . .โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(a)(2)(B).  However, in 
9  cases where a full report is not required under Rule 26(a)(2)(B), a party is required to disclose  
 
10  the  subject  matter  on  which  the  witness  is  expected  to  present 
evidence . . . [and] a summary of the facts and opinions to which the 
11  witness is expected to testify.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(a)(2)(C).   
  12  The Advisory Committee Notes explain that Rule 26(a)(2)(C) mandates โsummary disclosures of 
a
rt ni
ur
oo 13  the opinions to be offered by expert witnesses who are not required to provide reports under Rule 
Cif
t al
icC 14  26(a)(2)(B) and of the facts supporting those opinions.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 advisory committeeโs 
strof 
Dict  15  note to 2010 amendment (noting that physicians or other health care professionals are common 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  examples of witnesses exempt from Rule 26(a)(2)(B)โs written report requirement); see Goodman 
d Srn 
ee 17  v. Staples the Office Superstore, LLC, 644 F.3d 817, 826 (9th Cir. 2011) (treating physicians are 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  exempt from Rule 26(a)(2)(B)โs written report requirement to the extent that their opinions were 
19  formed during the course of treatment).   
20  If a party fails to disclose the facts and opinions to which non-retained experts would 
21  testify, that party has the burden to show โthe failure was substantially justified or is harmless.โ  
22  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(c); Goodman, 644 F.3d at 826.  In considering whether to exclude testimony, 
23  Rule 37 requires a court to consider the harm, if any, caused by the failure to comply, and provides 
24  alternative, lesser sanctions โinstead ofโ exclusion.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(c)(1); Pineda v. City & Cty. 
25 
                                                 
2 The Court notes that CFMG Defendants, in the Declaration of Peter G. Bertling, suggest that 
26 
their disclosures are sufficient as compared to Plaintiffsโ disclosures.  ECF 80-1 at 7.  This 
argument is unpersuasive and improperly raised in a declaration in violation of Civil Local Rule 7-
27 
5(b).  Civ. L. R. 7-5(b) (โAn affidavit or declaration may contain only facts, must conform as 
much as possible to the requirements of Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e), and must avoid conclusions and 
28 
argument.โ). 
3 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 88   Filed 05/10/17   Page 4 of 5
 
1  of San Francisco, 280 F.R.D. 517, 520 (N.D. Cal. 2012) (โLimiting the automatic sanction to 
2  violations โwithout substantial justificationโ coupled with the exception for violations that are 
3  โharmless,โ is needed to avoid unduly harsh penalties in a variety of situations.โ). 
4  III.  ANALYSIS  
5  The Court finds that CFMG Defendantsโ supplemental disclosures of Kelly and Greenleaf 
6  do not comply with Rule 26(a)(2)(C) because the disclosures, even after supplementation, do not 
7  contain a summary of the facts and opinions to which Kelly and Greenleaf will testify.  The 
8  disclosure required for non-retained experts under Rule 26(a)(2)(C) is โconsiderably less extensive 
9  than the report required by Rule 26(a)(2)(B).โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 advisory committeeโs note to 
10  2010 amendment.  However, the high level summary provided by CFMG Defendants provides 
11  only the most modest description imaginable (e.g., โauthenticationโ and โinterpretationโ) along 
  12  with a catchall category (โother issuesโ) that does nothing to narrow the universe on which Kelly 
a
rt ni
ur
oo 13  and Greenleaf may testify.  These descriptions do not, by themselves, satisfy Rule 26(a)(2)(C).   
Cif
t al
icC 14  In its opposition to Plaintiffsโ original motion, CFMG did not address Plaintiffsโ argument 
strof 
Dict  15  regarding non-retained experts, much less offer any argument as to why its lack of compliance 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  with Rule 26 is โsubstantially justifiedโ or โharmless,โ which could excuse it from the sanction of 
d Srn 
ee 17  exclusion.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(c)(1).  The Court cannot speculate as to whether the failure to 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  properly disclose Kelly and Greenleaf was substantially justified, but the failure to properly 
19  disclose is not harmless, particularly in light of the number of non-retained experts disclosed by 
20  CFMG Defendants.  Absent the disclosure required under Rule 26(a)(2)(C), Plaintiffs cannot 
21  make an informed decision on whether they should depose Kelly and Greenleaf.  If Plaintiffs 
22  choose to depose Kelly and Greenleaf, their ability to prepare for and conduct a meaningful 
23  deposition is undermined by not knowing in advance Kellyโs and Greenleafโs opinions and the 
24  main facts on which those opinions are based.   
25  Although CFMGโs failure to timely comply with Rule 26(a)(2)(C) is neither substantially 
26  justified nor harmless, and Plaintiffsโ objections have merit, the Court nonetheless will not impose 
27  the harsh sanction of excluding Kelly and Greenleaf entirely from testifying at trial.  Given the 
28  recent order by this Court and the fact that expert depositions are just getting underway, the Court 
4 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 88   Filed 05/10/17   Page 5 of 5
 
1  limits Kellyโs and Greenleafโs respective testimony as set forth below.   
2  Kelly:  Kelly may testify only regarding the authentication and interpretation of her 
3  relevant treatment records of and relevant communications with decedent, Jacob Parenti, or any 
4  other Plaintiff. 
5  Greenleaf:  Greenleaf may testify only regarding the authentication and interpretation of 
6  his relevant treatment records of and relevant communications with decedent, Jacob Parenti, or 
7  any other Plaintiff. 
8  Neither Kelly nor Greenleaf may offer testimony regarding any โother issues pertaining to  
9  . . . treatment records and treatment related to Mr. Parenti in connection with his health care at 
10  Avenal State Prison.โ   
11  IV.  CONCLUSION 
  12  The undersigned RECOMMENDS that the District Court, in the exercise of its discretion, 
a
rt ni
ur
oo 13  enter an order limiting the expert testimony of Julie Kelly, PA-C and Delmar Greenleaf, M.D. as 
Cif
t al
icC 14  directed above.  
strof 
Dict  15   
s ri
et
tatDis 16  SO RECOMMENDED.

documents.title: Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Plaintiffs' Motion to Exclude Duplicative and Inadmissible Expert Testimony; and Referring Rule 26 Disclosure Issues to Magistrate Judge Susan Van Keulen for Disposition
documents.text:
Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 1 of 11
 
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
8  SAN JOSE DIVISION 
9   
10  JACOB PARENTI, et al.,  Case No.  14-cv-05481-BLF    
 
11  Plaintiffs,  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
DENYING IN PART PLAINTIFFSโ 
  12  v.  MOTION TO EXCLUDE 
a
tr in   DUPLICATIVE AND INADMISSIBLE 
uoro 13  COUNTY OF MONTEREY, et al.,  EXPERT TESTIMONY; AND 
Cfi
 tla REFERRING RULE 26 DISCLOSURE 
ciC 14  Defendants.  ISSUES TO MAGISTRATE JUDGE 
rts fo SUSAN VAN KEULEN FOR 
iD tc 15    DISPOSITION 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    [Re:  ECF 76] 
S de nre 17       
th
intr
Uo
N 18    This action arises out of the death of thirty-three year old Jacob Parenti, who died in his 
19  cell at the Monterey County Jail where he was being held on a probation violation.  Plaintiffs are 
20  the Estate of Jacob Parenti, Mr. Parentiโs minor son, and Mr. Parentiโs mother.  Plaintiffs assert 
21  violations of federal and state law by Monterey County, Sheriff Scott Miller, and Deputy Collins 
22  (โCounty Defendantsโ), as well as California Forensic Medical Group and Dr. Taylor Fithian 
23  (โCFMG Defendantsโ). 
24    Plaintiffs assert that the CFMG Defendants have designated an excessive number of 
25  retained and non-retained experts who offer duplicative and/or inadmissible opinions, and that the 
26  CFMG Defendantsโ disclosures of non-retained experts did not comply with Federal Rule of Civil 
27  Procedure 26.  Plaintiffs also assert that the Countyโs retained experts offer inadmissible opinions.  
28  Plaintiffs ask the Court to (1) limit the CFMG Defendants to one retained expert on the topics of 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 2 of 11
 
1  cause of death and adequacy of medical care, (2) exclude inadmissible opinions of experts retained 
2  by the CFMG Defendants and the County Defendants, and (3) prohibit testimony by the CFMG 
3  Defendantsโs non-retained experts who were not adequately disclosed as required by Rule 26. 
4    For the reasons discussed below, Plaintiffsโ motion is GRANTED IN PART AND 
5  DENIED IN PART, and the Rule 26 disclosure issues are REFERRED to Magistrate Judge Susan 
6  van Keulen for disposition. 
7  I.  DISCUSSION 
8    A.  CFMG Defendantsโ Retained Experts โ Duplication 
9    Plaintiffs contend that the CFMG Defendants have designated multiple retained healthcare 
10  professionals who will offer duplicative and cumulative opinions regarding the cause of Mr. 
11  Parentiโs death and whether the medical services provided to Mr. Parenti met the standard of care.  
12  Plaintiffs ask the Court to exercise its discretion to limit CFMG to a single retained expert on these 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  topics.  In response, the CFMG Defendants assert that their retained experts come from different 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  backgrounds and thus offer different bases for their opinions, and that no one expertโs opinion 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  overlaps in its entirety with any other opinion.   
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    โThe court may exclude relevant evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed 
S d nr
ee 17  by a danger of . . . needlessly presenting cumulative evidence.โ  Fed. R. Evid. 403.  Moreover, the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Court has authority to limit the extent of discovery otherwise allowed by federal or local rules if 
19  โthe discovery sought is unreasonably cumulative or duplicative, or can be obtained from some 
20  other source that is more convenient, less burdensome, or less expensive.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 
21  26(b)(2)(C)(i). 
22    The Court finds it impossible to determine based on the current record whether exclusion 
23  of any of CFMGโs experts is appropriate under these standards.  Trial is not set to commence for 
24  eighteen months, and none of the experts has yet been deposed.  The Court understands that 
25  Plaintiffs brought this motion at least in part for the very purpose of avoiding the costs of those 
26  depositions.  See Olney Decl. ยถ 4 (โTo even depose each of CFMGโs experts at their required rates 
27  of up to $650 per hour, Plaintiffsโ costs and fees could easily exceed $30,000.โ), ECF 76-1.  
28  However, the CFMG Defendants have the right to designate the experts of their choice, and it does 
2 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 3 of 11
 
1  not appear โ at least on this record โ that there is complete overlap with respect to any one expert 
2  witness which would justify that expertโs exclusion.  There is no suggestion that the disclosure is 
3  in bad faith or for any improper purpose.  Accordingly, Plaintiffsโ request that the Court limit the 
4  CFMG Defendants to a single retained expert on the issues of cause of death and standard of care 
5  is DENIED. 
6    The Court does, however, direct the parties to meet and confer regarding the order of the 
7  depositions so that the retained experts who are most likely to testify are deposed first.  Plaintiffs 
8  may wish to depose the one or two experts most likely to testify and seek permission to conduct 
9  late depositions of the other experts after the close of discovery in the event such depositions 
10  become necessary.  In the event that experts who appeared most likely to testify are not called at 
11  trial, the Court would entertain a motion by Plaintiffs for cost-shifting with respect to the 
12  depositions of those experts.      
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    B.  CFMG Defendantsโ Retained Experts โ Admissibility 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Plaintiffs also challenge the admissibility of certain aspects of the opinions offered by two 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  of the CFMG Defendantsโ retained experts, Kimberly Pearson, R.N., and Frank Sheridan, M.D. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16      1.  Ms. Pearson 
S d nr
ee 17    Ms. Pearson, a Registered Nurse, offers opinions regarding the standard of medical care 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  provided to Mr. Parenti by the CFMG nursing staff and the cause of Mr. Parentiโs death.  See 
19  Pearson Report, Exh. 2 to Olney Decl., ECF 76-1.  Plaintiffs do not dispute Ms. Pearsonโs 
20  qualifications to offer such opinions.  However, Plaintiffs do object to Ms. Pearsonโs statements 
21  regarding other individualsโ state of mind as well as statements that could be construed as legal 
22  opinion.  For example, Ms. Pearson opines that the CFMG nursing staff โwere not subjectively 
23  aware whether or not Mr. Parenti had a serious medical condition beyond signs and symptoms of 
24  an upper respiratory infection in January 2014, and they did not consciously disregard his 
25  healthcare needs.โ  Id. at 14.  She also opines that โCFMG nursing staff did not attempt to harm 
26  Mr. Jacob Parenti.โ  Id. at 18.  Those opinions would be inadmissible at trial.  See Siring v. 
27  Oregon State Bd. of Higher Educ. ex rel. E. Oregon Univ., 927 F. Supp. 2d 1069, 1077 (D. Or. 
28  2013) (โCourts routinely exclude as impermissible expert testimony as to intent, motive, or state 
3 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 4 of 11
 
1  of mind.โ); Pinal Creek Grp. v. Newmont Mining Corp., 352 F. Supp. 2d 1037, 1043 (D. Ariz. 
2  2005) (expert witness may not give an opinion on a question of law). 
3    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Ms. Pearsonโs opinions 
4  regarding the state of mind of other individuals or questions of law.  Ms. Pearson may, however, 
5  testify regarding the conduct of individuals in response to properly stated questions. 
6      2.  Dr. Sheridan      
7    Dr. Sheridan, a pathologist, offers the opinion that the cause of Mr. Parentiโs death was 
8  acute heroin toxicity.  See Sheridan Report, Exh. 2 to Olney Decl., ECF 76-1.  Plaintiffs assert that 
9  Dr. Sheridanโs opinion is inadmissible because he failed to perform an adequate differential 
10  diagnosis.  โDifferential diagnosis, or differential etiology, is a standard scientific technique of 
11  identifying the cause of a medical problem by eliminating the likely causes until the most probable 
12  one is isolated.โ  Clausen v. M/V NEW CARISSA, 339 F.3d 1049, 1057 (9th Cir. 2003) (citation 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  omitted).  โThe first step in the diagnostic process is to compile a comprehensive list of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  hypotheses that might explain the set of salient clinical findings under consideration.โ  Id.  โAfter 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  the expert rules in all of the potential hypotheses that might explain a patientโs symptoms, he or 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  she must then engage in a process of elimination, eliminating hypotheses on the basis of a 
S d nr
ee 17  continuing examination of the evidence so as to reach a conclusion as to the most likely cause of 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the findings in that particular case.โ  Id. at 1058.  Federal courts generally have found properly 
19  conducted differential diagnoses to be admissible under Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, 
20  Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993).  Clausen, 339 F.3d at 1057.  However, a district court is justified in 
21  excluding evidence if the expert fails to explain why an alternative cause was ruled out.  Id. at 
22  1058. 
23    Plaintiffs appear to assume that Dr. Sheridan performed a differential diagnosis and they 
24  challenge the adequacy of that diagnosis based on Dr. Sheridanโs failure to rule out as a possible 
25  cause of death โ or even to address โ a finding in the Monterey County toxicology report that Mr. 
26  Parentiโs blood sample revealed a level of amitriptyline in the toxic range.  That argument is 
27  unpersuasive, because Dr. Sheridanโs report does not indicate that he utilized differential diagnosis 
28  methodology to reach his conclusion regarding cause of death.  See Sheridan Report, Exh. 2 to 
4 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 5 of 11
 
1  Olney Decl., ECF 76-1.  Dr. Sheridan states that his opinion is based on review of two separate 
2  autopsy reports, microscopic slides from both autopsies, toxicology reports, investigative reports, 
3  and other materials.  Id.  He notes that the autopsy report prepared by Monterey County 
4  determined the cause of death to be โAcute mixed drug intoxication,โ while the autopsy report 
5  prepared by Dr. David Posey determined the cause of death as โviral flu syndrome complicated by 
6  pneumonia, sepsis, systemic inflammatory response syndrome, septic shock and multi-organ 
7  system failure.โ  Id. at 125.  Dr. Sheridan then opines that โ[t]he evidence in this case points 
8  clearly to death being the result of acute heroin toxicityโ and gives his reasons for rejecting the 
9  conclusion of sepsis and organ failure presented in Dr. Poseyโs autopsy report.  Id.  Dr. Sheridan 
10  does not purport to address โall of the potential hypotheses that might explain a patientโs 
11  symptomsโ as would be required for a differential diagnosis.  See Clausen, 339 F.3d at 1058.  
12  Since it does not appear that Dr. Sheridan performed a differential diagnosis at all, Plaintiffsโ 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  argument that he did not perform an โadequateโ differential diagnosis provides no basis for 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  exclusion. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    To the extent that Plaintiffs argue that differential diagnosis is the only methodology which 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  may be used to determine cause of death, such argument is unsupported by the case law.  โWhile 
S d nr
ee 17  the Ninth Circuit has stated that โa reliable differential diagnosis passes muster under Daubert,โ it 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  has not required experts to use that method when reaching their conclusions.โ  Carrion v. United 
19  States, No. 2:13-cv-00419-RFB-NJK, 2016 WL 4087104, at *5 (D. Nev. July 28, 2016) (quoting 
20  Clausen, 339 F.3d at 1058).  Thus a district court need not exclude an expertโs opinion on 
21  causation simply because the expert did not apply differential diagnosis.  See Millenkamp v. 
22  Davisco Foods Intโl, Inc., 562 F.3d 971, 979 (9th Cir. 2009) (Exclusion was not warranted 
23  because expert โdid not purport to employ differential diagnosis, and Clausen does not preclude 
24  the use of all other methods to determine the cause of an illnessโ); Carrion, 2016 WL 4087104, at 
25  *5 (โWhile differential diagnosis is one universally accepted method for establishing medical 
26  causation in certain contexts, a plaintiff can nonetheless present expert medical testimony that 
27  does not include this method provided that it meets Rule 702โs threshold reliability requirement.โ). 
28    The cases cited by Plaintiffs are not to the contrary.  In Nelson and Whisnant, the Ninth 
5 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 6 of 11
 
1  Circuit held that the district courts had not abused their discretion in excluding expert opinions 
2  that expressly relied on differential diagnosis but failed to consider alternate causes.  Nelson v. 
3  Matrixx Initiatives, Inc., 592 F. Appโx 591, 592 (9th Cir. 2015); Whisnant v. United States, 274 F. 
4  Appโx 536, 537 (9th Cir. 2008).  In Morin, the Ninth Circuit held that the district court had not 
5  abused its discretion in concluding that the expertโs methodology was not sufficiently reliable 
6  where it was unclear whether or how the expert had applied differential diagnosis.  Morin v. 
7  United States, 244 F. Appโx 142, 143 (9th Cir. 2007).   
8    Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude Dr. Sheridanโs opinion for lack of an adequate differential 
9  diagnosis is DENIED.   
10    C.  County Defendantsโ Retained Experts โ Admissibility 
11    Plaintiffs also challenge the admissibility of the opinions offered by the County 
12  Defendantโs two retained experts, James Sida and Timur Durrani, M.D. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    1.  Mr. Sida 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Mr. Sida is offered as an expert on jail operations, policies and procedures.  Plaintiffs 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  contend that he goes well beyond that subject matter and offers numerous inadmissible legal 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  opinions, medical opinions, and other opinions outside the scope of his expertise.  The parties, and 
S d nr
ee 17  in particular the County Defendants, have provided what amounts to a line-by-line analysis of Mr. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Sidaโs lengthy report.  See Sida Report, Exh. 1 to Olney Decl., ECF 76-1.  The Court declines to 
19  address Mr. Sidaโs report at that level of detail at this stage of the proceedings, that is, before Mr. 
20  Sida is deposed and a year and a half before trial.  However, Plaintiffsโ motion is well-taken with 
21  respect to the categories of opinions they identify, as discussed below.    
22      a.  Legal Opinions 
23    โExpert testimony is admissible when it will assist the trier of fact in understanding the 
24  evidence or determining a disputed issue of fact.โ  Pinal Creek Grp., 352 F. Supp. 2d at 1042.   
25  However, experts may not opine about how the law should apply to the facts of a particular case.  
26  Id. โTestimony which articulates and applies the relevant law . . . circumvents the [fact finderโs] 
27  decision-making function by telling it how to decide the case.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and 
28  citation omitted) (alterations in original).   
6 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 7 of 11
 
1    Mr. Sida offers a number of opinions purporting to apply the relevant law to the facts of 
2  this case in a manner expressly prohibited by the above standards.  For example, he states that โit 
3  is clear to me that the Sheriff and County is [sic] not indifferent to crowding and other jail issues,โ 
4  and that โ[i]t is my conclusion that the medical services provided in the Monterey County Jail 
5  meet Constitutional requirements from a jail management perspective.โ  Sida Report, Exh. 1 to 
6  Olney Decl. at 24, 29, ECF 76-1.  These and all similar opinions would be excluded at trial. 
7    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Mr. Sidaโs legal opinions.  The 
8  Court notes that Mr. Sida does appear to be qualified to testify regarding jail management, 
9  policies, and practices.  Therefore, while some of his opinions are inartfully cast as legal opinions 
10  in his report, he may be able to testify regarding the underlying subject matter of those opinions in 
11  response to proper questioning. 
12      b.  Medical Opinions 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    โA witness who is qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  education may testifyโ if the expertโs โspecialized knowledge will help the trier of fact to 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue.โ  Fed. R. Evid. 702.  Mr. Sida is not a 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  medical professional, yet he offers medical opinions regarding the standard of medical care 
S d nr
ee 17  provided by the CFMG Defendants and the cause of Mr. Parentiโs death.  Plaintiffs cite numerous 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  examples of such opinions in their motion, only a few which are set forth here by way of example.  
19  Mr. Sida states that โI have found that the Monterey County Sheriffโs Department, by way of their 
20  jail staff, does provide adequate custodial medical care which meets the standard of medical care 
21  in the community.โ  Sida Report, Exh. 1 to Olney Decl. at 24-25, 29, ECF 76-1.  He also opines 
22  that โI believe that Mr. Parenti passed very quickly and therefore it would be unreasonable to 
23  expect that Deputy Collins could have foreseen the serious consequence of Mr. Parentiโs ingestion 
24  of heroin.โ  Id. at 35.  In another example, Mr. Sida โassert[s] that the Monterey County Sheriffโs 
25  Department and their medical service contractor, CFMG did, in fact, comply with professional 
26  standards established in the State of California, which includes competent and appropriate medical 
27  treatment to Mr. Parenti and their timely response in the emergency that preceded Mr. Parentiโs 
28  death.โ  Id. at 53.  These and similar medical opinions would be excluded at trial. 
7 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 8 of 11
 
1    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Mr. Sidaโs medical opinions.  
2  While Mr. Sida may not offer medical opinion regarding the adequacy of medical services actually 
3  provided to Mr. Parenti, he does appear to be qualified to testify regarding the appropriate level of 
4  medical services for which a facility such as the Monterey County Jail should contract.  
5      c.  Opinions Regarding Drug Smuggling 
6    Mr. Sida offers opinions regarding the smuggling of drugs into the Monterey County Jail.  
7  While he appears to be qualified to opine regarding drug smuggling in jails generally, his report 
8  does not disclose an adequate basis for his opinions regarding smuggling in Monterey County Jail 
9  in particular.  See Lopez v. I-Flow Inc., No. CV 08-1063-PHX-SRB, 2011 WL 1897548, at *10 
10  (D. Ariz. Jan. 26, 2011) (โUnder Rule 26, an expertโs written report must include an explanation 
11  of the basis and reasons for each expressed opinion.โ).  Accordingly, Mr. Sidaโs opinions 
12  regarding drug smuggling in the Monterey County Jail would be excluded at trial. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Mr. Sidaโs opinions regarding 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  drug smuggling at the Monterey County Jail.  He may testify regarding drug smuggling in jails 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  generally. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16      d.  Opinions Regarding In-Custody Deaths       
S d nr
ee 17    Mr. Sida also offers opinions regarding the statistical significance of the number of in-
th
intr
Uo
N 18  custody deaths that occurred at the Monterey County Jail.  For example, he opines that the three 
19  in-custody deaths that occurred in 2014 โare simply events and not trends relating to in custody 
20  deaths in the jail.โ  Sida Report, Exh. 1 to Olney Decl. at 39, ECF 76-1.  Mr. Sidaโs report does 
21  not identify any background, education, or training in the field of statistics.  He provides a chart 
22  comparing in-custody deaths in Monterey County with such deaths in fourteen other โcomparable 
23  counties,โ but he does not provide an adequate basis for limiting his comparison to the selected 
24  counties while excluding dozens of other California counties.  Accordingly, Mr. Sidaโs opinions 
25  regarding the statistical significance of the in-custody deaths at the Monterey County Jail would 
26  be excluded at trial. 
27    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Mr. Sidaโs opinions regarding 
28  the statistical significance of in-custody deaths at the Monterey County Jail. 
8 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 9 of 11
 
1      e.  Rebuttal Opinion 
2    โ[A] rebuttal expert cannot offer evidence that does not contradict or rebut another expertโs 
3  disclosure.โ  Theoharis v. Rongen, No. C13-1345RAJ, 2014 WL 3563386, at *3 (W.D. Wash. July 
4  18, 2014).  Plaintiffs argue that portions of Mr. Sidaโs rebuttal report to one of Plaintiffsโ experts, 
5  Jeffrey Schwartz, go beyond mere rebuttal and are intended to buttress opinions offered in Mr. 
6  Sidaโs own expert report.  See Sida Rebuttal Report, Exh. 10 to Olney Decl., ECF 76-2.  Plaintiffsโ 
7  argument is well-taken, and the County Defendants offer no meaningful opposition.   
8    Plaintiffโs motion to exclude is GRANTED with respect to Mr. Sidaโs rebuttal opinions 
9  which do not actually contradict or rebut Mr. Schwartzโs opinion.    
10    The Court notes that the County Defendants argue that the rebuttal report of Plaintiffsโ 
11  expert, Mr. Schwartz, also exceeds the permissible scope of rebuttal evidence.  The County 
12  Defendants have not moved to exclude testimony of Plaintiffsโ expert, and thus their argument 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  regarding Mr. Schwartzโs rebuttal report is not addressed in this order. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    2.  Dr. Durrani 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Dr. Durrani offers opinions primarily regarding the services provided by the Monterey 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  County Public Health Department.  See Durrani Report, Exh. 1 to Olney Decl., ECF 76-1.  For 
S d nr
ee 17  example, he opines that the Department โacted appropriately in assisting the jail by balancing the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  needs to protect public health while not placing an onerous burden on the jail, the staff and the 
19  inmates.โ  Id. at 78.  Dr. Durrani further opines that the Public Health Department โmeets the 
20  standard of care expected of local health officers when dealing with disease outbreaks in 
21  correctional facilities.  Id. at 79.  Plaintiffs contend that Dr. Durrani is not qualified to give these 
22  and similar opinions because he does not have any background in the correctional field.  Plaintiffs 
23  also contend that Dr. Durrani does not actually offer any original analysis but merely parrots the 
24  deposition testimony of Ms. Kristy Michie. 
25    The Court concludes that Dr. Durrani may testify on topics within his area of expertise, 
26  such as the functioning of the Monterey County Public Health Department and the standard of 
27  care for a county public health department.  However, the Court is troubled by Dr. Durraniโs 
28  opinions regarding a correctional facilityโs ability to implement commonly applied public health 
9 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 10 of 11
 
1  techniques for identifying the nature of a contagious pathogen and mitigating its transmission.  It 
2  appears that Dr. Durrani has relied on Ms. Michieโs testimony regarding the correctional facilityโs 
3  capabilities.  To the extent that Dr. Durraniโs opinions are based solely on Ms. Michieโs testimony, 
4  they will be excluded at trial.  See Depโt of Toxic Substances Control v. Technichem, Inc., No. 12-
5  CV-05845-VC, 2016 WL 1029463, at *1 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 15, 2016) (excluding expert opinion in 
6  part because expert โoften does no more than regurgitate information given to him by other 
7  sourcesโ). 
8    At the hearing counsel for the County Defendants stated that Dr. Durraniโs opinions are 
9  offered only to counter any claim of liability based on deficiencies by the Monterey County Public 
10  Health Department, not to bolster the Countyโs position regarding the jailโs response.  Insofar as it 
11  is not clear whether this issue will be presented at trial, and the County Defendantsโ clarification 
12  of Dr. Durraniโs potential testimony, the Court is not prepared to exclude Dr. Durrani entirely at 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  this time. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Accordingly, Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude Dr. Durrani is GRANTED to the extent that his 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  opinions are based solely on Ms. Michieโs testimony and otherwise is DENIED.    
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    D.  CFMG Defendantsโ Non-Retained Experts โ Rule 26 Disclosure Issues 
S d nr
ee 17    Finally, Plaintiffs argue that the CFMG Defendantsโ non-retained experts should be 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  stricken because the CFMG Defendantsโ disclosures did not satisfy Federal Rule of Civil 
19  Procedure 26.  The Rule 26 disclosure issues raised by Plaintiff are REFERRED to Magistrate 
20  Judge Susan van Keulen for disposition.  Judge van Keulenโs chambers will contact counsel if 
21  Judge van Keulen wishes supplemental briefing or oral argument on these issues. 
22  II.  ORDER      
23    IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT: 
24    (1)  Plaintiffsโ request that the Court limit the CFMG Defendants to a single retained  
25      expert on the issues of cause of death and standard of care is DENIED; 
26    (2)  Plaintiffโs motion to exclude Ms. Pearsonโs opinions regarding the state of mind of 
27      other individuals and questions of law is GRANTED; 
28    (3)  Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude Dr. Sheridanโs opinions is DENIED; 
10 

Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 87   Filed 05/03/17   Page 11 of 11
 
1    (4)  Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude Mr. Sidaโs opinions is GRANTED IN PART as to the 
2      categories of opinions identified in this order and otherwise is DENIED; 
3    (5)  Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude Dr. Durraniโs opinions is GRANTED IN PART as to 
4      opinions based solely on Ms. Michieโs testimony and otherwise is DENIED; and 
5    (6)  Plaintiffsโ motion to exclude the CFMG Defendantsโ non-retained experts for  
6      failure to comply with Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26 is REFERRED to  
7      Magistrate Judge Susan van Keulen for disposition.

COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES     
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page2 of 22
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  On January 15, 2014, Defendants left Jacob Parenti, a 33 year-old man 
3  in Monterey County Jail for a probation violation, lying unconscious, helpless, and 
4  untreated on his dorm bed to die.  Through this lawsuit, Plaintiffs seek to hold 
5  Defendants accountable for refusing to provide basic health care to Mr. Parenti, 
6  resulting in his death. 
7  2.  At the time of Jacob Parentiโs death in January 2014, the Jail was 
8  already the subject of a federal putative class action lawsuit regarding systemic 
9  failures to provide adequate medical and mental health care, resulting in 
10  unnecessary harm, suffering, and death.  However, the County, its Sheriff and 
11  officers have stubbornly refused to address these known issues and to adopt 
12  policies, procedures, and practices to provide minimum standards of treatment for 
13  inmates.  
14  JURISDICTION 
15  3.  This Complaint seeks damages for the violation of the civil rights, 
16  privileges, and immunities guaranteed by the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth 
17  Amendments of the United States Constitution, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 1983 and 
18  1988, as well as for violations of California state law.   
19  4.  This Court has jurisdiction over this lawsuit pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 
20  1331 and 1343. 
21  5.  This Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the state law claims 
22  asserted herein pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1367, because the claims form part of the 
23  same case or controversy arising under the United States Constitution and federal 
24  law. 
25  VENUE 
26  6.  Plaintiffsโ claims, alleged herein, arose in the County of Monterey, 
27  California. Venue therefore lies in the Northern District of California pursuant to 28 
28  U.S.C. ยง 1391(b)(2). 
   
-1- 
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES 
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page3 of 22
 
1  7.  Rule 3 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Local Rule 3-2(e) 
2  authorizes assignment to this division because a substantial part of the events or 
3  omissions giving rise to Plaintiffsโ claims occurred in the counties served by this 
4  division. 
5  PARTIES 
6  8.  Plaintiff D.P-O. is the seven year-old minor son and sole heir of Jacob 
7  Parenti.  Plaintiff D.P-O. brings his individual claims by and through Matthew 
8  Oberholtz, his legal guardian. They reside in Butte County, California.   
9  9.  Plaintiff D.P-O. also brings claims on behalf of the Estate of Jacob 
10  Parenti, by and through his legal guardian Matthew Oberholtz, pursuant to 
11  California Code of Civil Procedure ยงยง 377.10 et seq. At the time of his death, Jacob 
12  Parenti was a 33 year-old citizen of the United States and resident of the County of 
13  Monterey in the State of California.  The survival causes of action in this matter are 
14  based on violations of Jacob Parentiโs rights under the U.S. Constitution and 
15  California state law. 
16  10.  Plaintiff Susan Parenti is the mother of Jacob Parenti, and resides in 
17  Monterey County, California. She is suing individually for violations of civil rights 
18  under the First and Fourteenth Amendments and California state law. 
19  11.  Defendant County of Monterey is a public entity, duly organized and 
20  existing under the laws of the State of California. Under its authority, Defendant 
21  County of Monterey operates and manages Monterey County Jail and is and was at 
22  all relevant times mentioned herein responsible for the actions and/or inactions and 
23  the policies, procedures, and practices/customs of the Monterey County Sheriffโs 
24  Office and Monterey County Jail, and each entityโs respective employees and/or 
25  agents. Monterey County Sheriffโs Office operates Monterey County Jail, and is 
26  and was responsible for ensuring the provision of emergency and medical and 
27  mental health care services to all Monterey County Jail inmates.  Monterey County 
28  Sheriffโs Office also operates the Office of the Coroner. 
   
-2- 
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES 
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page4 of 22
 
1  12.  Defendant Scott Miller is, and was at all relevant times mentioned 
2  herein, the Sheriff-Coroner of the County of Monterey, the highest position in the 
3  Monterey County Sheriffโs Office. As Sheriff-Coroner, Defendant Miller is and 
4  was responsible for the hiring, screening, training, retention, supervision, discipline, 
5  counseling, and control of all Monterey County Sheriffโs Office custodial 
6  employees and/or agents.  Defendant Miller is and was charged by law with the 
7  administration of the Monterey County Jail, and is responsible for safety and 
8  security of inmates housed at the Jail.  Defendant Miller also is and was responsible 
9  for the promulgation of the policies and procedures and allowance of the 
10  practices/customs pursuant to which the acts of the Monterey County Sheriffโs 
11  Office alleged herein were committed.  As Sheriff-Coroner, Defendant Miller is 
12  also charged with oversight of the Coronerโs Division of the Monterey County

3  FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
4  I.  History of Inadequate Medical Care in Monterey County Jail 
5  19.  County of Monterey, Monterey County Sheriffโs Office, CFMG, and 
6  Taylor Fithian have been on notice that their provision of medical care to inmates at 
7  the Monterey County Jail is inadequate and results in needless harm and suffering 
8  since at least 2007, when the Monterey County Sheriffโs Office and the Monterey 
9  County Board of Supervisors hired an outside consulting firm to perform a needs 
10  assessment for the Jail. (See Ex. 1.) The 2007 Assessment concluded that the Jail 
11  was severely overcrowded, lacked adequate numbers of staff, and that 
12  โmedical/mental health treatment spaces are not adequate for the rated beds, let 
13  alone the actual number of inmates held.โ (Ex. 1 at 1, Executive Summary at 1.)  It 
14  further concluded that shortfalls in staffing result in hiring of โpre-academyโ 
15  officers, unmanageable supervision loads for first line supervisors, and insufficient 
16  staff on some shifts to make required safety checks. The Monterey County Board of 
17  Supervisors accepted the report by unanimous vote on June 19, 2007.    
18  20.  At the request of Defendant Miller, the independent assessment was 
19  updated in 2011 and found that County of Monterey physical facilities and their 
20  policies and practices for delivering medical treatment remained inadequate. The 
21  2011 Assessment similarly found that the Jailโs โMedical/mental health treatment 
22  spaces are not adequate for the rated beds, let alone the actual number of inmates 
23  heldโ and therefore prevent adequate delivery of medical health care. (Ex. 2, 
24  Executive Summary at 3.) The 2011 Assessment further noted the direct impact on 
25  overcrowding on prisonersโ overall health, stating that โOvercrowding affects 
26  inmatesโ mental and physical health by increasing the level of uncertainty with 
27  which they regularly cope.โ (Ex. 2, Executive Summary at 9.)

18  88.  The aforementioned acts and/or omissions of Defendants in being 
19  deliberatively indifferent to Jacob Parentiโs serious medical needs, health and 
20  safety, violating Mr. Parentiโs constitutional rights, and their failure to train, 
21  supervise, and/or take other appropriate measures to prevent the acts and/or 
22  omissions that caused the untimely and wrongful death of Jacob Parenti deprived 
23  Plaintiffs Susan Parenti and D.P-O. of their liberty interests in the parent-child 
24  relationship in violation of their substantive due process rights as defined by the 
25  First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. 
26  89.  As a direct and proximate result of the aforementioned acts and/or 
27  omissions of Defendants, Plaintiffs suffered injuries and damages as alleged herein. 
28  / / /  
   
-16- 
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES 
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page18 of 22
 
1  90.  The aforementioned acts and/or omissions of Defendants Miller, in his 
2  individual capacity, Collins, CFMG, and Fithian were willful, wanton, malicious, 
3  and oppressive, thereby justifying an award to Plaintiffs of exemplary and punitive 
4  damages to punish the wrongful conduct alleged herein and to deter such conduct in 
5  the future.   
6  Third Claim for Relief 
7  Failure to Furnish / Summon Medical Care  
8  (Survival Action โ California State Law) 
9  (Against All Defendants) 
10  91.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 
11  90 as though fully set forth herein. 
12  92.  Defendants owed Jacob Parenti a duty of care to provide him 
13  immediate medical care. 
14  93.  The conduct of Defendants alleged herein, including but not limited to 
15  the facts that Defendants knew or had reason to know that Jacob Parenti was in 
16  need of immediate medical care and that Defendants failed to take reasonable 
17  action to summon or provide that care, resulting in Jacob Parentiโs death as alleged 
18  herein, violated California state law, including Cal. Govt. Code ยงยง 844.6 and 845.6. 
19  94.  The alleged conduct of Defendants was committed within the course 
20  and scope of their employment. 
21  95.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendantsโ breach, Jacob Parenti 
22  and Plaintiffs suffered injuries and damages causing great pain and leading to 
23  Parentiโs death, as alleged herein. 
24  96.  The aforementioned acts and/or omissions of Defendants Miller, in his 
25  individual capacity, Collins, CFMG, and Fithian were willful, wanton, malicious, 
26  and oppressive, thereby justifying an award to Plaintiffs of exemplary and punitive 
27  damages to punish the wrongful conduct alleged herein and to deter such conduct in 
28  the future.   
   
-17- 
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES 
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page19 of 22
 
1  Fourth Claim for Relief 
2  Negligent Supervision, Training, Hiring, and Retention  
3  (Survival Action โ California State Law) 
4  (Against Defendants County of Monterey, Miller, CFMG, and Fithian) 
5  97.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 
6  96 as though fully set forth herein. 
7  98.  Defendants had a duty to hire, supervise, train, and retain employees 
8  and/or agents so that employees and/or agents refrain from the conduct and/or 
9  omissions alleged herein. 
10  99.  Defendants breached this duty, causing the conduct alleged herein. 
11  Such breach constituted negligent hiring, supervision, training, and retention under 
12  the laws of the State of California. 
13  100.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendantsโ failure, Jacob Parenti 
14  and Plaintiffs suffered injuries and damages as alleged herein. 
15  Fifth Claim for Relief 
16  Negligence (Survival Actions โ California State Law) 
17  (Against All Defendants) 
18  101.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 
19  100, as though fully set forth herein. 
20  102.  Defendants failed to comply with professional standards in the 
21  provision of medical care to Jacob Parenti by failing to appropriately assess and 
22  evaluate his medical needs, failing to provide timely and emergency medical 
23  attention, failing to provide appropriate medical treatment, and failing to adopt the 
24  minimum policies, procedures, and training necessary to ensure identification of 
25  and response to of medical emergencies. 
26  103.  These Defendants also failed to appropriately supervise, review, and 
27  ensure the competence of medical staffโs and custody staffโs provision of treatment 
28  to Parenti, and failed to enact appropriate standards and procedures that would have 
   
-18- 
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES 
 
 
 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document1   Filed12/16/14   Page20 of 22
 
1  prevented such harm to him.  
2  104.  Together, these Defendants acted negligently and improperly, 
3  breached their respective duties, and as a direct and proximate result, Plaintiffs 
4  suffered injuries and damages as alleged herein. 
5  105.  The negligent conduct of Defendants was committed within the course 
6  and scope of their employment. 
7  106.  The aforementioned acts and/or omissions of Defendants Miller, in his 
8  individual capacity, Collins, CFMG, and Fithian were willful, wanton, malicious, 
9  and oppressive, thereby justifying an award to Plaintiffs of exemplary and punitive 
10  damages to punish the wrongful conduct alleged herein and to deter such conduct in 
11  the future.   
12  Sixth Claim for Relief 
13  Wrongful Death โ California Code Civ. Proc. ยง 377.60 
14  (Against All Defendants) 
15  107.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 
16  106, as though fully set forth herein. 
17  108.  Jacob Parentiโs death was a direct and proximate result of the 
18  aforementioned wrongful and/or negligent acts and/or omissions of Defendants.  
19  Defendantsโ acts and/or omissions thus were also a direct and proximate cause of 
20  Plaintiffsโ injuries and damages, as alleged herein. 
21  109.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendantsโ wrongful and/or 
22  negligent acts and/or omissions, Plaintiffs incurred expenses for funeral and burial 
23  expenses in an amount to be proved. 
24  110.  As a direct and proximate result of Defendantsโ wrongful and/or 
25  negligent acts and/or omissions, Plaintiffs suffered the loss of the services, society, 
26  care, and protection of the decedent, as well as the loss of the present value of his 
27  future services to his mother and son.  Plaintiffs are further entitled to recover 
28  prejudgment interest.

1  111.  The aforementioned acts and/or omissions of Defendants Miller, in his 
2  individual capacity, Collins, CFMG, and Fithian were willful, wanton, malicious, 
3  and oppressive, thereby justifying an award to Plaintiffs of exemplary and punitive 
4  damages to punish the wrongful conduct alleged herein and to deter such conduct in 
5  the future.   
6  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
7  WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray for the following relief: 
8  1.  For compensatory, general and special damages against each 
9  Defendant, jointly and severally, in an amount to be proven at trial; 
10  2.  For damages related to loss of familial relations as to Plaintiffs Susan 
11  Parenti and D.P-O.; 
12  3.  Funeral and burial expenses, independent autopsy expenses, and 
13  incidental expenses not yet fully ascertained; 
14  4.  General damages, including damages for physical and emotional pain, 
15  emotional distress, hardship, suffering, shock, worry, anxiety, sleeplessness, illness 
16  and trauma and suffering, the loss of the services, society, care and protection of the 
17  decedent, as well as the loss of financial support and contributions, loss of the 
18  present value of future services and contributions, and loss of economic security; 
19  5.  Prejudgment interest;

3  engaging in similar misconduct; 
4  7.  For costs of suit and reasonable attorneysโ fees and costs pursuant to 
5  42 U.S.C. ยง 1988, and as otherwise authorized by statute or law; 
6  8.  For restitution as the court deems just and proper; 
7  9.  For such other relief, including injunctive and/or declaratory relief, as 
8  the Court may deem proper.

Estate of Jacob Parenti v. County of Monterey, et al.  Case No.  CV 14-05481-PSG 
Joint Case Management Statement and [Proposed] Order 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document33   Filed04/21/15   Page3 of 16
 
1    Plaintiffs Estate of JACOB PARENTI, deceased, by and through 
2  MATTHEW OBERHOLTZ, D.P-O., a minor, by and through his guardian, 
3  MATTHEW OBERHOLTZ, and SUSAN PARENTI (โPlaintiffsโ), and 
4  Defendants County of Monterey, Sheriff Scott Miller, Officer Collins, California 
5  Forensic Medical Group, and Taylor Fithian, M.D. (โDefendantsโ), hereby submit 
6  this Joint Case Management Statement and [Proposed] Order pursuant to the 
7  Standing Order for All Judges of the Northern District of California dated July 1, 
8  2011, and Civil Local Rule 16-9. 
9  1.  Jurisdiction and Service: 
10    a.  Jurisdiction 
11    This Court has jurisdiction over Plaintiffsโ federal claims pursuant to 28 
12  U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1343, and over Plaintiffsโ state law claim pursuant to 28 
13  U.S.C. ยง 1367. 
14    b.  Venue 
15    The parties do not anticipate any issues regarding personal jurisdiction or 
16  venue. 
17    c.  Service 
18    All Defendants were personally served with the Complaint herein. 
19  2.  Facts: 
20    a.  Plaintiffsโ Statement 
21  On January 15, 2014, Defendants left Jacob Parenti, a 33 year-old man in 
22  Monterey County Jail for a probation violation, lying unconscious, helpless, and 
23  untreated on his dorm bed to die.  At the time of Jacob Parentiโs death, the Jail was 
24  already the subject of a class action lawsuit regarding systemic failures to provide 
25  adequate medical care.  However, the County, its Sheriff and officers have 
26  stubbornly refused to address these known issues.    
27    Mr. Parenti began a one-year jail term for a probation violation at Monterey 
28  County Jail on or around August 1, 2013.  On or around January 10, 2014, Mr. 
3 
 
Estate of Jacob Parenti v. County of Monterey, et al.  Case No.  CV 14-05481-PSG 
Joint Case Management Statement and [Proposed] Order 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document33   Filed04/21/15   Page4 of 16
 
1  Parenti developed flu-like symptoms.  He followed the Jailโs procedures for 
2  seeking medical care and put in a written sick call request.  Around the same time 
3  period, Mr. Parenti began coughing up blood.  Mr. Parenti did not receive a 
4  medical appointment in response to the sick call request he put in on January 10, 
5  2014.  He put in another sick call request slip on or around January 12.  Mr. Parenti 
6  continued coughing up blood that was thick and mucous-like.  He was not called 
7  for sick call January 13 or 14.    
8  At around 9:45 a.m. on January 15, Defendant Collins called for Mr. Parenti 
9  to see the nurse.  Mr. Parenti was laying on his bunk and did not and could not 
10  respond.  Defendant Collins entered D-wing, walked to Mr. Parentiโs bunk, and 
11  said his name several more times.  Mr. Parenti remained unresponsive.  Defendant 
12  Collins then repeatedly tapped and/or shook Mr. Parenti, but Mr. Parenti remained 
13  unresponsive.   
14  Deputy Collins then left D-wing without providing or summoning 
15  emergency or other medical attention for Mr. Parenti.  Over the next hour, 
16  Defendants failed, refused, and/or neglected to provide medical attention to an 
17  inmate in their custody in obvious and serious need of immediate medical 
18  attention.  
19  At approximately 10:45 a.m., inmates in Mr. Parentiโs housing unit noticed 
20  that he had stopped breathing and his face had a bluish tint.  Several inmates pulled 
21  him down from the bunk and attempted to resuscitate him while other inmates 
22  attempted to get the attention of the deputies.  After one inmate had already started 
23  CPR on Mr. Parenti, deputies arrived in the unit, followed by Fire Department 
24  personnel and nurses.  On information and belief, the Jail deputies did not attempt 
25  CPR on Mr. Parenti. 
26  At 11:05 a.m. on January 15, 2014, Mr. Parenti was pronounced dead.  
27  In the evening of January 15, 2014, Susan Parenti, Mr. Parentiโs mother, 
28  received a phone call from an inmate at Monterey County Jail during which the 
4 
 
Estate of Jacob Parenti v. County of Monterey, et al.  Case No.  CV 14-05481-PSG 
Joint Case Management Statement and [Proposed] Order 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document33   Filed04/21/15   Page5 of 16
 
1  inmate informed her that Mr. Parenti had died.  Ms. Parenti had not previously 
2  received any notification of her sonโs death from Defendants. 
3  Although the Monterey County Coronerโs Report eventually concluded that 
4  Mr. Parenti died due to acute mixed drug intoxication, toxicology analysis of Mr. 
5  Parentiโs blood does not support this conclusion.  Based on the findings of the 
6  independent autopsy, Parentiโs death resulted from viral influenza syndrome 
7  complicated by pneumonia, a treatable medical condition.    
8    b.  Defendants County of Monterey, Sheriff Scott Miller and Officer 
9  Collinsโ Statement 
10    Defendants County of Monterey, Sheriff Scott Miller and Officer Collins 
11  (โCounty Defendantsโ) deny that they singularly or individually caused decedent 
12  Jacob Parentiโs injury or death.   
13    On July 20, 2013, Jacob Parenti was arrested in the City of Seaside, County 
14  of Monterey, for violation of Vehicle Code 23152(a); under the influence of, and in 
15  possession  of  a  controlled  substance,  receiving  stolen  property,  and  probation 
16  violation.  Parenti pled guilty to various charges and was sentenced to County jail 
17  on August 1, 2013 with a release date of September 18, 2014.  Parenti was housed 
18  in D-Wing on January 15, 2014.  On the morning of January 15, 2014, an inmate in 
19  D-Wing, hearing Parentiโs name called for โmed passโ, attempted to wake him up 
20  as he appeared to be sleeping.  Parenti, in response, waved the inmate off.  The 
21  inmates believed  Parenti  was  sleeping.   Defendant  Collins, when he  contacted 
22  Parenti, was given the same response.  Parenti ate breakfast and nothing unusual 
23  was noted in his appearance or manner. 
24    Parenti was seen in the front area of D-Wing at about 9:15 a.m., as he left 
25  the area and returned to his bunk, as he returned to see a television program he 
26  regularly watched. 
27    Later that morning, various inmates noted that Parenti seemed to be having 
28  trouble breathing.  Various inmates signaled for help and removed Parenti from his 
5 
 
Estate of Jacob Parenti v. County of Monterey, et al.  Case No.  CV 14-05481-PSG 
Joint Case Management Statement and [Proposed] Order 

Case5:14-cv-05481-PSG   Document33   Filed04/21/15   Page6 of 16
 
1  bunk to the cell floor.  Jail staff responded at about 10:40 a.m. and found Parenti 
2  unresponsive.  Medical staff was called and lifesaving measures were employed.  
3  Medical staff arrived, assessed Parenti and called for paramedics, who responded 
4  at 11:00 a.m., but Parenti was propounded dead at approximately 11:05 a.m.  The 
5  conclusion of the postmortem examination was that Parenti died from an acute 
6  mixed drug intoxication. 
7    c.  Defendants California Forensic Medical Group, Inc. and Taylor 
8  Fithian, M.D.โs Statement 
9  For his most recent incarceration, Mr. Parenti was booked into the Monterey 
10  County Jail on July 20, 2013.  On intake, he provided a history of heart problems 
11  and anxiety, and reported taking Klonopin, Atenolol, Lisinopril and hydrocodone.  
12  He was placed on a low sodium diet and blood pressure checks were ordered and 
13  performed daily for five days, then weekly in the hypertension clinic.  Throughout 
14  the remainder of 2013, Mr. Parenti was properly seen and treated by physicians 
15  and staff from CFMG with appropriate medication renewals and adjustments.  Mr. 
16  Parenti was also properly examined and treated by CFMG physicians and staff for 
17  mental health and psychiatric care.  In the fall of 2013, Mr. Parenti complained of a 
18  skin growth under his nose, which was timely evaluated and monitored by CFMG 
19  physicians and staff and plaintiff was referred to an outside dermatologist, Dr. 
20  Friend, in November 2013 for biopsy and treatment, which biopsy was performed 
21  on January 6, 2014 and presumed to represent basal cell carcinoma. 
22  On January 10, 2014 Mr. Parenti submitted a single sick call slip stating 
23  โhave the flu.โ  He was scheduled and seen at sick call on January 13, 2014 at 
24  10:30 a.m. by Maureen Hollcraft.  During this examination, Mr. Parenti reported 
25  he had the flu and his joints were sore.  His vital signs, including temperature, were 
26  normal.  His throat was red, tongue was coated and he had slight swelling in his 
27  nodes.  Ms. Hollcraft assessed an upper respiratory infection and noted she would 
28  be discussing Mr. Parenti with an โM.D.โ (Dr. Garcia), which was done 
6

1  approximately one and a half hours later.  Orders were written for a decongestant 
2  (Actifed), cough medicine (Robitussin), and an analgesic (Motrin).   These 
3  medications were begun with the late afternoon pill pass on January 13, 2014. 
4  Subsequently, on January 14, 2014 at 1555, Mr. Parenti was seen for a 
5  mental health examination by Charlotte Gage.  Mr. Parenti was anxious related to 
6  his current basal cell carcinoma diagnosis but his speech was clear and his thought 
7  process was organized.  He requested an increase in his psychiatric medications 
8  and Ms. Gage noted she would discuss the request with Dr. Fithian, which was 
9  done on January 15, 2014 at 0900.   However, at approximately 1045 hours on 
10  January 15, 2014, CFMG staff was summoned to D-wing where custody was 
11  amidst life-saving efforts for Mr. Parenti.   CFMG staff including physician Dr. 
12  Benda continued life-saving efforts and summoned an ambulance but Mr. Parenti 
13  was propounded dead at approximately 11:05 a.m.  The postmortem examination 
14  concluded Mr. Parenti died from an acute mixed drug intoxication.

26  Civil Procedure 26.  See Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Plaintiffsโ Motion to Exclude, 
27  ECF 87.  Judge van Keulen recommends that the Court deny the motion to exclude Kelly and
