Case 5:14-cv-05481-BLF   Document 92   Filed 06/06/17   Page 2 of 2
 
1    The Court finds the Report and Recommendation to be correct, well-reasoned, and 
2  thorough.  Specifically, the Court agrees with Judge van Keulen that the CFMG Defendantsโ 
3  disclosures regarding Kelly and Greenleaf do not comply with Rule 26(a)(2)(C) and that the 
4  appropriate remedy is to limit the witnessesโ testimony to the disclosures which were provided.  
5  See R&R at 4-5, ECF 88.   
6    Accordingly, the Court: 
7    (1)  ADOPTS the Report and Recommendation in its entirety; and

9      Recommendation.    
10

1  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
2  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA

OF MINORโS CLAIMS

9  Defendants. 
   
10   
11  Plaintiff D.P-O, a minor, by and through his guardian Mathew Oberholtz, individually and 
12  on behalf of the Estate of Jacob Parenti, together with Plaintiff Susan Parenti petition the Court for 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  an order approving the partiesโ proposed settlement, and of the settlement on behalf of a minor 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  included therein.  Mot., ECF 136.  For the reasons stated below, the Court GRANTS the motion. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  I.  BACKGROUND1 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Minor D.P-O, by and through his legal guardian Matthew Oberholtz, as an individual and 
S d nr
ee 17  on behalf of the Estate of Jacob Parenti, along with his grandmother Susan Parenti (collectively, 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  โPlaintiffsโ), filed this action against Defendants County of Monterey (โCountyโ), Scott Miller, 
19  Officer Collins, California Forensic Medical Group, and Taylor Fithian, M.D., alleging six causes 
20  of action:  (1) deliberate indifference to serious medical needs and failure to protect from harm in 
21  violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983; (2) deprivation of 
22  substantive due process in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments, under 42 U.S.C. ยง 
23  1983; (3) failure to furnish or summon medical care, under California state law; (4) negligent 
24  supervision, training, hiring, and retention, under California state law; (5) negligence, under 
25  California state law; and (6) wrongful death, under California Civil Procedure Code ยง 377.60.  See 
26  generally Compl., ECF 1. 
27 
                                                 
1 This section is based on allegations made in the Complaint.  The Court accepts these allegations 
28 
as true for the purposes of ruling on this motion.  

 
1  Susan Parenti is the mother of Jacob Parenti (โMr. Parentiโ).  Id. ยถ 10.  Mr. Parenti lived 
2  with his mother in his youth.  Compl. ยถ 30.  When he was older, he regularly helped his mother, by 
3  doing household chores and acting as her caretaker.  Compl. ยถ 38.  D.P-O is the seven-year-old2 
4  minor son and sole heir of Mr. Parenti.  Compl. ยถ 8.  After D.P-O was born in 2007, he lived with 
5  his birth mother, but he had an ongoing relationship with Mr. Parenti, who made child support 
6  payments, visited regularly, and brought D.P-O to spend time with Mr. Parentiโs family.  Compl. ยถ 
7  32.  In 2013, Mr. Parenti was awarded primary custody of D.P-O and brought D.P-O to live with 
8  him in Monterey, California.  Compl. ยถยถ 34โ35.  When Mr. Parenti was incarcerated in February 
9  2013 for three months, his cousin, Matthew Oberholtz cared for D.P-O.  Compl. ยถ 36.  Mr. Parenti 
10  began a separate period of incarceration in August 1, 2013 at Monterey County Jail (โJailโ), 
11  during which he kept in regular contact with his son, his mother, and his other family members.  
12  Compl. ยถยถ 40โ42.   
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Throughout the first few months of his incarceration, Mr. Parenti told his mother that the 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Jail was not providing him with his prescribed blood pressure and psychotropic medications.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Compl. ยถ 44.  His mother complained to the Jail many times and even brought his medications to 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  the Jail and gave them to the nurse to ensure that Mr. Parenti received them.  Compl. ยถ 44.  On or 
S d nr
ee 17  around both January 10 and January 12, 2014, Mr. Parenti reported to the staff that he thought he 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  had the flu.  Compl. ยถยถ 45, 47.  He was not called for sick call.  Compl. ยถ 48.  Around January 10, 
19  Mr. Parenti began to cough up blood, and this continued throughout the next few days.  Compl. ยถยถ 
20  46, 48. 
21  On January 15, at breakfast around 3:45 a.m., Mr. Parenti appeared awake and alert.

22  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
23  โDistrict courts have a special duty, derived from Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 17(c), to 
24  safeguard the interests of litigants who are minors.โ  Robidoux v. Rosengren, 638 F.3d 1177, 1181 
25  (9th Cir. 2011).  โRule 17(c) provides, in relevant part, that a district court โmust appoint a 
guardian ad litemโor issue another appropriate orderโto protect a minor or incompetent person 
26 
who is unrepresented in an action.โโ  Id. (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 17(c)).  โIn the context of 
27 
proposed settlements in suits involving minor plaintiffs, this special duty requires a district court 
28 
3 

 
1  to โconduct its own inquiry to determine whether the settlement serves the best interests of the 
2  minor.โโ  Id. (quoting Dacanay v. Mendoza, 573 F.2d 1075, 1080 (9th Cir. 1978)). 
3  In cases involving the settlement of a minorโs federal claims, a district court must consider 
whether the proposed settlement is fair and reasonable as to each minor plaintiff.  Id. at 1182.  
4 
โ[T]he district court should evaluate the fairness of each minor plaintiffโs net recovery without 
5 
regard to the proportion of the total settlement value designated for adult co-plaintiffs or plaintiffsโ 
6 
counselโwhose interests the district court has no special duty to safeguard.โ  Id.  
7 
While the Robidoux Court expressly limited its holding to settlement of a minorโs federal 
8 
claims, โdistrict courts have found the Robidoux rule reasonable in the context of state law claims 
9 
and have applied the rule to evaluate the propriety of a settlement of a minorโs state law claims as 
10 
well.โ  Frary v. Cnty. of Marin, Case No. 12-cv-03928, 2015 WL 3776402, at *1 (N.D. Cal. June 
11 
16, 2015); see also Mitchell v. Riverstone Residential Grp., No. S-11-2202, 2013 WL 1680641, at 
12 
a 
tr in *1 (E.D. Cal. Apr. 17, 2013) (collecting cases).  California law, which governs the state law
